comment.narrative: 1. Research and analysis on current marine IAS distribution and pathways in Turkeys coastal zones, 2. Identification of methods to measure and analyse the impact of marine IAS. 3. Terms of reference for relevant consultants will be prepared. 4. Meetings will be held with the GD of Fisheries and Aquaculture and other key local stakeholders to design the incentive mechanism, identify the target species. Detailed activity plan on incentive program will be prepared. 5. Members of the Working Group of the Ballast Water Convention will be selected and invited by official letters. 6. Details of the participants list, terms of reference of the Board and methods of working will be identified. The draft for Ministerial Decree on national coordination mechanism decree will be outlined. 7. The terms of reference for database consultants will be prepared and the notice will be advertised. The stakeholder consultation meetings will be held to identify the preliminary needs and existing tools regarding the database. 8. A communication and awareness raising program will be prepared for the project. Also, a monitoring system will be designed to measure the impact of the program and will be initiated. 9. The content of data collection program will be identified with the leadership of Chief Technical Advisor of the project. Terms of references for related consultants/ consultant roosters will be drafted and notices will be advertised.

1. It was decided to hold a workshop in November 2019 in order to bring together relevant academicians, expert NGOs and experts and to analyze the current legislation. 2. The report for the determination of analysis methodologies will be prepared in December 2019. 3. Terms of reference for relevant consultants (quarantine mechanisms, bio-security, legal) were prerapred and submitted to UNDP. 4. It was agreed that the incentive program consultant should prepare the relevant report by the end of November 2019. Following the preparation of the report, it was decided to hold a meeting with the Fisheries and Fisheries GM on a date to be determined by the DKMP (December 2019). 5. Meeting was held with UAB on Thursday, 11 July 2019 and the relevant meeting notes were shared with all participants. The decisions taken at the meeting will be followed; a-Establishment of Ballast Water National Technical Working Group, b-Database feasibility studies, c-Organization of Ballast Water International Symposium (2020-2021), d-Ballast Water Sampling (E-DNA) supported by the IYT project. 6. It is planned to have the necessary official correspondence with the National Technical Advisory Board and to meet with the relevant institutions in December 2019. 7. The analysis report of the relevant expert for the Accessible MarIAS database was completed and submitted to UNDP in September 2019. 8. A meeting with UAB was held on Thursday, 11 July 2019 and stated that the maritime sector does not need any capacity mapping needs. This activity will be monitored for re-evaluation next year (2020). 9. Project Logo and IAS corporate identity work were completed and the outputs were shared with UNDP in July 2019. 10. A communication and awareness program draft was prepared for the project and submitted to UNDP in May 2019. 11. Evaluation reports on current Legislation Analysis of IAS and Project Boards and Working Groups were prepared, shared with DKMP in July 2019. 12. PIU planned to visit all project sites; Hatay / Samandağ visit was realized on 9-12 October 2019 and local stakeholder workshop was organized.

1.1.Regulation on introduction, early detection, prevention and management of IAS in marine and coastal wetland ecosystems developed and will be submitted for adoption. 1.3.2.Development of sector-specific guidelines on protocols and quarantine mechanisms for marine IAS particularily in 3 sectors (will be defined) that impact/being impacted by IAS other than shipping. 1.4.1 Design of incentive mechanism with specific implementation instructions will be confirmed with all partners. 1.4.2.Outreach program designed on fiscal incentives for the local communities (and nature/conservation related NGOs) for each study site. 1.4.5 Harvest incentive program in partnership with local communities will be developped in Hatay-SAamandağ and in Marmara Islands. 1.5.1 National Technical Working Group on implementation of the Ballast Water Convention will be established. 1.5.7 Practical workshop on eDNA sampling and analysis will be organized in order to increase capacity of MoTI personnel on ballast water and sediment to support implementation of National Ballast Water Strategy and Ballast Water Convention. 1.6.5 Draft of the National Strategy and Action Plan on marine IAS will be initiated, TerrIAS project will lead. 2.1.1. Ministerial Decree on national coordination mechanism (Advisory Technical Board) drafted and submitted for adoption. 2.2.2 The database and its web interface for open access marine IAS database (with official list of prohibited IAS, modules on risk analysis, early warning response and monitoring for IAS in marine and coastal ecosystems) will be constructed. 2.2.3 Development of database module, or separate database, to support implementation, monitoring, and enforcement of Ballast Water Convention in collaboration with MoTI. 2.4.2 Development of training modules and programs on control of marine IAS with the collaboration of ARCD, CTA and Marmara Field Expert. 2.4.3.Design and printing of training and awareness raising materials + Audio Visual Product such as Marıas Animation Video, Puffer Fish and Jelly Fish short movies. 2.4.12 First phase of Monitoring the awareness in target groups will be finalized. 2.4.13 Study visits for capacity building of staff of related Institution (2x if the Covid-19 allows) will be organized. 3.1.1 Data collection for completion of project site marine IAS management plans; identification of site-specific measures for prevention, ensure eradication, control and management of IAS will be defined.

1.1 In cooperation with EU funded project to address IAS in Terrestrial Areas (TerIAS) project, a draft regulation, the By-law on Control and Management of IAS in line with EU legislation has been prepared by taking the opinions of the all the key stakeholders and submitted to GDNCP. 1.3.2 The Evaluation Meeting on the Content of the Protocols and Quarantine Mechanisms regarding marine invasive alien species was held in June 2021. Biosecurity guidelines for 3 sectors (recreational yachting, marine divers and marine aquarium trade) are preprared. Attendees agreed on the content of the guidelines that will be finalized and disseminated in 1Q 2022. 1.4.1 Due to the existing incentive program for Pufferfish and a high commercial value of sea snails, it was decided that a specific incentive program is not needed Since the sea snails are being extensively harvested by commercial fishers therefore a specific incentive program for the harvest was not deemed necessary by the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry. 1.4.2 An Evaluation Meeting on Incentive Mechanisms for Combating Marine Invasive Alien Species (IAS) was held in June 2021; financial incentive programs for Water hyacinth, Lionfish and North Atlantic starfish, which are among the target species within the scope of the project, were assessed as unsuitable and unsustainable. It was decided to prepare a non-fiscal incentive program instead. The report was shared with the attendees; the proposed target species were evaluated, and the design was validated. 1.4.5 Puffer fish Harvest Incentive Program, Lion fish Harvest Incentive Program and Water hyacinth Harvest Incentive programs are designed/preprared and will be shared with the GDNCP to get the final validation. 1.5.1 The project team held regular meetings with GDM and agreed to explore methods, such as e-DNA (environmental DNA) systems, for monitoring ballast water. The National Working Group establishment is denied/refused by the GDM, besided the impact of the project on these issue is limited. 1.5.7 Practical workshop on capacity building of MoTI personnel working in sampling and analysis of ballast water and sediment, to support implementation of National Ballast Water Strategy and Ballast Water Convention, including demonstration of eDNA sampling and analysis was held in in September 2021. Twelve (12) practical guidelines related to Ballast Water Convention were translated from EN to TR in April 2021. 1.6.5 The needs and strategy framework were determined in close partnership with the TerIAS project, both projects agreed on the common strategy outline. The National Strategy and Action Plan for IAS will be developed following a participatory and multi-stakeholder approach proposing an applicable and replicable set of actions to prevent alien invasion and minimize the adverse effects in 2022. 2.1.1 The National Technical Advisory Board, for which a draft Presidential Decree defining the structure, members and operating principles has been prepared in cooperation with TerIAS project in consultation with the relevant institutions and submitted to the beneficiary following stakeholder consultations by the end of 2020, has not convened yet due to the internal decision-making processes of the Ministry. 2.2.2 The existing national IAS list has been updated. The roadmap towards the national marine IAS database scope/content/structure/access and entry evaluation and validation protocols were determined in cooperation with the GDNCP. In line with the remarks of the GDNCP, the database will be constructed and pilot data entry will be carried out in 1Q 2022. The database is planned to be operated and maintained by GDNCP. 2.2.3 The development of database module within the enforcement of Ballast Water Convention was refused/denied by GDM-MoTI. 2.4.2 The content of the training module on Awareness raising has been developed by the ARCD expert and a meeting was held on 12 August 2020 to explain and consult how the training activities will be carried out in the field with the contribution of IAS experts. Awarennes Raising training for 3 groups (transport, divers, fishermen) conducted between 03-04-05 November 2021 in Antalya. Species cards are designed and printed as well. 2.4.3 Designed and printed awareness raising materials; - 12 IAS species were defined by the field experts and illustrations of the selected IAS were included in the MarIAS Calendar 2021. More than 3,000 copies were printed and distributed to relevant NGOs, governmental institutions and regional directorates of GDNCP. (December 2020) - A short animation video was also produced to raise the knowledge and understanding of marine IAS. (June 2021) - Concluding a contract with ÖRAV (Turkish Teachers Academy Foundation) through Responsible Party Agreement within the scope of the Teacher and Student Education program that was prepared and submitted to PIU in April 2021 by ARCD expert. (4Q 2021) - Production of a documentary on MarIAS (about 30min) (4Q 2021) - Procurement of Şahika Ercümens Deniz Kızı ve Delfi Book, a world record holder free diver and “Life Below Water” Advocate of UNDP). This edition was printed specifically for MarIAS project including MarIAS content. More than 3,000 copies were printed and distributed tregional directorates of GDNCP. (December 2021) 2.4.12 “Analysis of socio-economic impacts of marine IAS in Turkey’s marine and coastal ecosystems” will be prepared by a socio-economic expert in 1Q 2021 based on the results of the first phase of Monitoring the level of awareness of target groups at the project pilot sites survey conducted in the 2Q of 2021 to determine the baseline. 2.4.13 Study Visit (2X) for Turkey-Belize-Florida South-South Knowledge Exchange & Development to Support Development plan for Lionfish, was prepared but cancelled due to the Visa restrictions between US and Turkey in July-August 2021. Another Study Visit (to Egypt) was planned/organized and unfortunately cancelled due the internal approvals within GDNCP. 3.1.1 The fieldwork methods to be carried out regularly were shared with GDNCP and UNDP project teams. The current marine Invasive Alien Species (IAS) distribution and pathways in Turkeys coastal zones were discussed on 16-17 February 2021 in Ankara. Regular detection and delimiting surveys that are being conducted as part of the project at the moment are expected to continue under the national IAS strategy and included in the key site management plans after 2023. The priority pathways have been identified and confirmed as a result of a desk study presented as a Scientific Publication on ‘Update on Key Pathways and Distribution of Marine IAS in Turkey’ released in May 2021.

1. Regulations on introduction, early detection, prevention and management of IAS in marine and coastal wetland ecosystems developed. 2) Main pathway and vectors for IAS identified. 3) It is planned to organize a technical meeting in pilot areas in the light of updated analyzes. 4) Protocols and quarantine mechanisms consistent with bio-security requirements and international standards for IAS in marine and coastal wetland ecosystems in place. 5) Fiscal incentives introduced for effective removal of IAS (e.g. Lion fish, Balloon fish) in marine and coastal wetland ecosystems (to encourage selective fishing and removal of IAS by fishers) jointly with Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MoFA). 6) Support implementation of National Ballast Water Strategy and Ballast Water Convention, including demonstration of eDNA sampling and analysis. 7) Along with PIU, CTA and ARCD, the website name, content and the technical specification including the Citizen Science developed. 8) Investigation of ecological and socio-economic impact of selected marine IAS. 9) Increased knowledge and awareness on IAS threats, impacts, management options and best practices for relevant industries, enterprises (aquaculture, transport, custom, tourism, etc.) media, security forces (gendarme), schools etc. 10) Data collection for the completion of the project site IAS management plans activities (with activity 1.6.1 - 1.6.3 - 3.1.1)

1.1) The draft legislation by the project legal expert was prepared. 1.2) Pre-evaluation with the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, General Directorate of Law was conducted. 2) Report concerning the collection of data on existing regional marine IAS distribution and pathway in Turkey was completed in February 2020 by Project Chief Technical Advisor and submitted to UNDP and GDNCP. 3) Technical meetings was held at 2 pilot sites; Hatay-Samandağ, Ayvalık Islands. 4.1) Quarantine/biosecurity specialist was recruited. 4.2) The expert report containing the current situation and recommendations and sector needs was submitted to UNDP in June 2020. 4.3) A meeting was held in July 2020 in order to evaluate the report by GDNCP and GDFA. 5.1) Incentive expert hired. 5.2) The first expert report containing current status and recommendations for incentive mechanism design was submitted to UNDP in June 2020, a technical meeting held to evaluate the report in July, 2020. 6) In the scope of supporting the implementation of eDNA sampling and analysis, 2 separate meetings were held on September 02, 2020 with the participation of the Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure (UAB) and nvironmental Sciences Faculty Member Dr. Ulaş TEZEL on September 16, 2020. 7) The construction of the website was completed in June 2020 and was opened to the public on 02 July. The EN version of the page went live in August 2020. 8) The socio-economic expert was recruited. 9.1) The determination of the main target groups and the first draft of the general communication strategy was prepared and submitted to the DKMP. 9.2) IAS documentary (IAS effect on Public Health) has been finalized The relevant video was shared on both MoAF and UNDPs social media. -Additional Video: A short film about lion fish was shot in Kas-Fethiye. -Additional Activity: The entire September issue and visual materials of Kafa Cocuk ve Bilim magazine have been prepared and designed for the MarIAS project. 9.3) The content of the training module on Awareness raising has been determined by ARCD and CTA. A meeting was held on 12 August 2020 to explain and consult how the activities will be carried out in the field with the contribution of IAS experts. 9.3) The number of infographics was determined as 11 by ARCD and IAS experts, they were completed and sent to the design firm. 10.1) IAS field experts started work on 02 June 2020. 10.2) A meeting was held on 11 August 2020 to identify the methods for measuring and analyzing the impact of Marine IAS and the habitats open to IAS invasion. 10.3) IAS field experts conducted field research and dives at relevant points in Hatay-Samandağ, Ayvalık - Marmara Islands and İğneada between 02-12 September 2020.
